content.question:
The random variable <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> takes on the values of 2, 5, <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and 15. The probability distribution of <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the following table.
<math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> 2 5 <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> 15 <math alttext="the probability of X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.1 0.4 0.2 0.3 
The expected value of <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is 9.1. What is the value of <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>Â ?

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

topic.text: 4.8: Mean and Standard Deviation of Random Variables

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Determine parameters for probability distributions.
